Rees-Mogg could be sued over fracking

Jacob Rees-Mogg is “facing legal action over his decision to lift the freeze on fracking”, according to The Independent. Climate and community groups have sent a legal letter to the business secretary, seen by the paper, announcing their plan to seek judicial review of his decision. The activists believe they are grounds to suggest that it was “unlawful” to reverse the 2019 ban on the controversial gas extraction method without fresh scientific evidence to prove it is safe. Meanwhile, Labour is pushing for fracking to be banned “once and for all” through a parliamentary vote.

search_result.title: Ultimate Coachella guide 2017: Lady Gaga, Kendrick Lamar ...
search_result.text:
Ed Masley

The Republic | azcentral.com

Coachella set the standard for the modern destination festival, an “If you build it, they will come” approach that revolutionized the industry, paving the way for Bonnaroo and inspiring Lollapalooza to come in off the road and pitch a tent in Chicago.

We’re about to get our own new destination festival in downtown Phoenix when Superfly, the co-creators of Bonnaroo and Outside Lands, unveil the will Lost Lake Festival at Steele Indian School Park the weekend of Oct. 20-22.

And after nearly 20 years, Coachella continues to thrive, now presenting the same three-day experience on consecutive weekends, April 14-16 and 21-23.

Coachella Day 3 review: Kendrick Lamar goes heavy on new music, Hinds and Twin Peaks rock, Lorde returns

The schedule is out now and as usual there are some tough decisions to be made.

Here’s a look at this year’s headliners, some other major draws worth seeing and some smaller bands you’d do well not to skip because you didn’t want bother with the names in little print on the Coachella poster.

FRIDAY HEADLINER: Radiohead

The most important British rockers of the past few generations are taking the stage in support of last year’s masterful “A Moon Shaped Pool,” a breathtaking journey that finds them filtering the digital experiments of “Kid A” and “Amnesiac” through lush orchestration that adds to the drama while underscoring the heavy emotional weight of Thom Yorke’s vocals. When they launched the tour that brings them to Coachella in late March, the critic at Miami New Times summed up just how big a deal a pilgrimage to Indio to see them headlining Coachella is for countless music nerds: “Nearly a quarter-century after the release of its debut album and exactly 20 years out from its international breakthrough with ‘OK Computer,’ this is a band with nothing left to prove and no one to impress. Any one of its most lauded albums — ‘OK Computer,’ ‘Kid A,’ ‘In Rainbows’ — could have earned the group a spot on modern music's Mount Rushmore, and Radiohead is widely regarded as one of the best live bands in the world.” And as I wrote when last they made a stop here in the Valley (in 2012), “Veteran acts as ambitious as Radiohead aren't often found selling out venues the size of a Jobing.com Arena. And the fact that they continue to connect on such a massive scale without the slightest hint of compromise just makes it even more impressive.” (10:35 p.m. Coachella stage)

SATURDAY HEADLINER: Lady Gaga

How do you solve a problem like Beyonce’s doctors realizing a woman having twins should not be headlining a major music festival? This is as good a fix as any, I suppose, although Rihanna may have spoken more to the Beyonce demographic. There aren't many artists alive who do high-concept pop-music spectacle better than Gaga. Among the more successful pop stars of the century, her hits include the multi-platinum smashes "Just Dance," "Poker Face," "Paparazzi," "Bad Romance," "Born This Way,” “Edge of Glory,” "You and I” and “Applause.” There’s also “Telephone,” a triple-platinum Top 5 hit that found her joining forces with the woman she’s replacing at Coachella. And she killed it at the Super Bowl in early February. As I noted at the time, the stage design was as extravagant as you'd expect, its futuristic look a perfect fit for the Bowiesque costume she wore at the top of her set before changing into something far more football-centric, with shimmering shoulder pads. The production was brilliantly choreographed, complete with mid-air acrobatics, and it definitely lived up to the promise of a huge pop spectacle, complete with a sky full of drones to create the illusion of a starry night. (11:20 p.m. Coachella Stage)

SUNDAY HEADLINER: Kendrick Lamar

After building a buzz on the strength of 2011's "Section.80," the Compton rapper broke through in a big way with the platinum "good kid, m.A.A.d city." The most acclaimed rap album of 2012, it sent "Swimming Pools (Drank)" to No. 1 on Billboard's rap chart, following through with two more major hits, "Poetic Justice" and "Bitch, Don't Kill My Vibe." He won his first two Grammys for “i,” the lead single from the most acclaimed release of 2015, “To Pimp a Butterfly” (which then went on to win a best rap album Grammy). A collection of demos from “Butterfly,” “untitled, unmastered,” topped the charts in 2016, the same year Lamar made Time magazine’s list of the 100 most influential people in the world, alongside Caitlyn Jenner, Lin-Manuel Miranda and Aziz Ansari. It would be wrong to not include one other point of interest from 2016. Asked who he believe to be the better rapper, Lamar or Drake, no lesser an authority than President Barack Obama chose Lamar. So, how is he live? He was great when he headlined the Pot of Gold Music Festival at Tempe Beach Park two before “To Pimp a Butterfly” hit the streets. More recently, the Guardian responded to a U.K. concert with: “One of the most exciting artists in the world exceeded expectations with a generous and unflagging show.” (10:25 p.m. Coachella)

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED STAR ATTRACTIONS

You don't want to limit yourself to just the names in big type on that poster, but you should consider these for sure.

FRIDAY: Father John Misty

His darkly comic narratives, often sung in character, have marked Father John Misty as his generation’s Randy Newman – not that I see Pixar work in Misty’s future. Released a week before Coachella, “Pure Comedy” is guaranteed to figure prominently on the shortlist of the year’s most celebrated albums, a third straight triumph for the singer-songwriter. Mojo said this album lifts him “to another level altogether,” while the Skinny raved: “He embraces the role, plays up to it, uses it to bend and manipulate the parameters of modern rock music and has managed to create something bitingly acerbic and cynical, yet achingly sincere. Again.” He topped our playlist of best February singles with a track from “Pure Comedy” called “Ballad of the Dying Man,” on which he turns his darkly comic eye for detail on a self-important know-it-all who wonders on his deathbed if he’s “successfully beaten back the rising tide of idiots, dilettantes and fools on his watch.” (7:20 p.m. Coachella Stage)

FRIDAY: The xx

The xx are playing Coachella in support of the recently released "I See You," which includes their most successful U.S. singles, "On Hold" and "Say Something Loving." The U.S. dates follow a historic European tour, including a record-setting, seven-night run at the O2 Academy Brixton in London, marking the longest-ever run of sold-out shows at the legendary venue, performing to 35,000 people over seven hometown performances. Long before that, they took home the Mercury Prize in 2010 for their acclaimed debut, a self-titled effort that also topped a year-end list at The Guardian. (8:50 p.m. Coachella Stage)

FRIDAY: Travis Scott

Best known in the mainstream for the double-platinum single “Antidote,” this Texas rapper is topping the bill at the Outdoor Stage in support of a chart-topping album, “Birds in the Trap Sing McKnight.” XXL called it “a roller coaster ride of an experience, with an endless amount of highlights, whether it be an indelible hook here or timely guest verse there.” His singles most likely to get a huge reaction include his breakthrough hit “3500” and the platinum “Pick Up the Phone” and “Goosebumps.” (9:35 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

FRIDAY: Phantogram

Josh Carter and Sarah Barthel set the tone for their forthcoming third album, "Three," with a breathtaking ballad called "Funeral Pyre" that Carter says was recorded for "Voices," their previous effort, and later reshaped with new lyrics to serve as the perfect transition into where they are today. And as the album makes its way through such obvious highlights as the hard-grooving heartache of "You Don't Get Me High Anymore" and cutting-edge pop classicism of "Cruel World," it's clear that "Three" is just the next step in an evolution that's taken Phantogram from "Eyelid Movies" to where they are now, offering a slightly different take on who they are at every turn. (8 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

FRIDAY: Mac DeMarco

The Canadian singer-songwriter most likely to perform nude (with apologies to Gordon Lightfoot) is playing Coachella a few weeks too early to say it’s in support of “This Old Dog,” his much-anticipated followup to “Another One.” DeMarco is known for two things – songs that reach inside your soul and force you to reflect on what you’ve done and how you plan to make it right, and being a total goof onstage. A bit Paul Westerberg in that respect. And as Smokey Robinson, who may not have been writing specifically about DeMarco, could tell you, “There’s some sad things known to man / But ain't too much sadder than the tears of a clown.” (5:25 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

FRIDAY: The Avalanches

These crate-digging Australians earned raves in 2001 for the sample-driven magic of a debut titled “Since I Left You,” which spawned two of the more inspired music videos you're likely to experience. The A.V. Club called it “quite possibly the best sample record ever made.” And it’s easy to see why they would go with that particular distinction. The album feature no fewer than 600 samples of recordings dating from the 1950s to the present day, crediting each sample in the liner notes. Of course that wouldn’t have mattered as much if it hadn’t resulted in such a willfully eccentric masterpiece. And then they went away, returning last year with another classic album titled "Wildflower." As the Independent heard it, "The wonderful 'Wildflower' is cause for celebration, its Zappa/Beasties-style collage of voices, samples, beats, sounds, and especially laughter offering a joyous affirmation of life." (6:45 p.m. Mojave Stage)

FRIDAY: Little Dragon

These Swedish electro-pop sensations are playing Coachella the very day they're set to hit the streets with "Seasons High," the long-awaited followup to "Nabuma Rubberband," a Grammy-nominated album to which Clash magazine responded, "Live, Little Dragon are weapons-grade ace. Now they’ve finally got an album to match." And when you see them at Coachella, they'll be live, which is "weapon-grade ace." The key to their appeal is, as always, lead singer Yukimi Nagano, who's toured with Gorillaz. (9:45 p.m. Gobi Stage)

FRIDAY: DJ Shadow

Last year marked the 20th anniversary of DJ Shadow's groundbreaking debut, an experimental hip-hop masterstroke called "Endtroducing." It's been cited as one of the decade's best by Q, SPIN, Pitchfork and Rolling Stone, whose critic raved, “The dystopian New Age of 'Endtroducing' sounds like an alien spacecraft touching down on the autobahn late at night, probably to check out Earth's used-vinyl bins,” adding, “This is DJ culture at its boldest: steeped in the past but zooming into the Space Age future.” But rather than rest on those seminal laurels, the DJ added to his legacy with 2016's "The Mountain Will Fall," an album that found him exploring new, less sample-driven territory. "Overall," the AV Club responded, "this is DJ Shadow’s best work since his early-aughts heyday. Whatever difficult terrain he had to scale to wrangle this mountain was worth the trip, and suggests even greater ascents in the future." (9:30 p.m. Mojave Stage)

FRIDAY: Sohn

Sohn is Christopher Taylor, whose latest collection of soulful yet haunting electropop, "Rennen," earned raves from Clash Music, Uncut and the 405, whose critic said it found him "diving into new creative depths, and triumphing." The Line of Best Fit also loved it, writing: "As a soundtrack to a new era where we’re all through the looking glass, old certainties bonfired and every phone alert quickening the pulse, 'Rennen' hits the right tone – its rhythms shivering and uneasy, its melodies veering from melancholy to euphoria in a single stride." (3:45 p.m. Gobi Stage)

FRIDAY: Empire of the Sun

This Australian synth-pop duo features Luke Steele of the Sleepy Jackson and Nick Littlemore of Pnau. They're best known in the States for platinum breakthrough single "Walking in a Dream." The Observer responded to "Two Vines," their latest release, with an amusingly back-handed rave: "Yes, it’s over-AutoTuned, and the ballads are still rubbish. But this somehow smooshes Cut Copy, ELO and Daft Punk into a honeyed mess that leaves you licking the bowl and twitching for more." (10:05 p.m. Sahara)

FRIDAY: Mac Miller

This Pittsburgh rapper may be best known in the mainstream for his featured rap on Ariana Grande’s hit, “The Way.” But he’s been ready for a mainstream moment for at least six years now, dropping would-be breakthroughs as eager to please as “Frick Park Market,” “Party on Fifth Ave.” and “Smile Back.” And he’s shown what once would have been thought of as “surprising” signs of growth along the way to last year’s model. "The Divine Feminine" is Miller at his most ambitious and most soulful. As Pitchfork said, “It’s easily his most intoxicating release yet, an odyssey of soulful compositions paring down his expansive and eclectic soundboard from the last few years into something distinctly cozy and pleasant.” (7:15 p.m. Sahara)

FRIDAY: Banks

The soulful electropop singer is set to reveal a new live set and visual at Coachella, promising “a very special performance in every sense.” Her latest album, “The Altar,” made good on the promise of a debut titled “Goddess” when it hit the streets last year. There’s a vulnerability she brings to such obvious highlights as “F—k With Myself” and “Mind Games” that really taps into the essence of the lyrics and mines them for all their potential catharsis. And “This is Not About Us” proves that she can also bring the swagger with the best of them. (7:10 p.m. Gobi)

SATURDAY: Bon Iver

Justin Vernon took the blogosphere by storm in 2008 with “For Emma, Forever Ago,” a rustic, acoustic-guitar-driven masterpiece written and recorded in a cabin in the woods, and picked up Best New Artist and Best Alternative Music Album four years later after releasing a self-titled triumph that built on the buzz of “For Emma” while taking his sound in a bold new direction. Last year, a third Bon Iver album, “22, A Million” made the rounds of critics’ year-end lists with good reason. The reviewer at Pretty Much Amazing compared it to what Friday’s headliner achieved on “Kid A,” with its futuristic digital manipulation of Vernon’s lead vocals and general purposeful digital glitchery, writing, “Not since ‘Kid A’ has an album so superb pushed away and pulled closer its audience, simultaneously and with such aplomb.” (9 p.m. Coachella Stage)

SATURDAY: Future

This Atlanta-based rapper engaged in a full-court blitz in 2015 that resulted in one of hip-hop’s most impressive winning streaks of all time. In under a year, he achieved three back-to-back No. 1 appearances on Billboard’s album chart -- the platinum “DS2,” the platinum “What A Time To Be Alive” with Drake, and “EVOL.” So what has done for us lately? Well, this year, for instance, he's already sent two records -- "Future" and "HNDRXX" -- to the top of Billboard's album chart. His best-known songs include the double-platinum smashes “Low Life” (featuring the Weeknd) and “Where Ya At” (with Drake), as well as the platinum hits “Stick Talk,” “F--k Up Some Commas,” and “Turn On The Lights.” His biggest hits, of course, is "Jumpman," a quadruple-platinum Drake collaboration. This should definitely be among the weekend's most anticipated sets. (7:30 p.m. Coachella Stage)

SATURDAY: Nicolas Jaar

An experimental electronic artist whose rep is based in part of a five-hour improvisational concert at MoMA PS1, as presented by Pitchfork, Jaaar earned raves for last year's "Sirens," a second album whose highlights ranged from an 11-minute opener whose ambient textures echoed David Bowie's work with Brian Eno to tracks that rocked the electronic rockabilly swagger like classic Suicide. PopMatters says, "Like Radiohead’s twin post-Y2K masterpieces — "Kid A" and "Amnesiac" — or Flying Lotus’s jazz-psych odysseys, it strips elements from pop and experimental music and fuses them into a new holistic world." Experimental art is rarely this approachable and daring in the same breath. (10:40 p.m.)

SATURDAY: DJ Snake

This French producer earned a Grammy nomination for his work on Gaga’s “Born This Way” in 2012 and a second nomination in 2015 for the video to the quadruple-platinum breakthrough that remains his biggest-selling hit, “Turn Down For What,” which featured Lil Jon. And that’s just one of several major hits the man can draw on, others being “You Know You Like It,” “Lean On,” “Middle” and the Justin Bieber team-up “Let Me Love You.” (10 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

SATURDAY: Schoolboy Q

Last year's "Blank Face LP," the West Coast rapper’s long-awaited followup to “Oxymoron,” features guest appearances by Kanye West (who appears on the hit single, "That Part"), Vince Staples, Jadakiss, E-40, Tha Dogg Pound, Anderson Paak, Miguel and Justine Skye. Consequence of Sound said, "It’s hard and sinister like a gangster rap album, but it’s also sprawling and even psychedelic at times. Nothing else sounds like it, and that’s a joy to behold." (8:25 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

SATURDAY: Gucci Mane

This Atlanta rapper first made a name for himself in 2005 with an album called “Trap House” and its breakthrough single, “Icy.” He really hit his stride, though, in 2009 with “The State vs. Radric Davis,” which sent three singles to the Top 10 on the rap charts, including his biggest hit, “Wasted.” After serving a two-year prison term, the star returned to active duty last summer with an album titled “Everybody Looking” and released two more before the year was out. (10:35 p.m. Sahara)

SUNDAY: Lorde

I’m still not sure what made her want to dance like that on “Saturday Night Live.” But hopefully the feeling’s passed, because the songs I’ve heard so far from her new album, “Melodrama,” have already made it clear that 2013’s “Pure Heroine,” the singer’s platinum debut, was no fluke (especially “Liability,” a Bowiesque piano ballad that feels like a page being torn from a diary in a really vulnerable moment). Lorde was all of 17 when "Royals" spent nine weeks at No. 1 on Billboard's Hot 100, selling 7.5 million copies worldwide. And she scored a second multi-platinum U.S. hit with “Team” from that same debut album. She hasn’t toured since late 2014, so TV show appearances are all we have to go on at the moment as far as what fans can expect from this performance. (8:45 p.m. Coachella Stage)

SUNDAY: Porter Robinson & Madeon

Rolling Stone magazine called Robinson one of the 25 DJs that rule the earth. And he won MTVu's Artist of the Year in March, 2015. That same year, he dropped a brilliant album titled "Worlds," on which the Chapel Hill, N.C., EDM producer appeared to have taken the title of a track called "Sad Machine" as a statement of purpose, sounding like the saddest machine in the saddest ruins of the saddest post-apocalyptic universe on several of the album's strongest tracks, of which there are many. He shares a stage at Coachella with Madeon, the French DJ with whom he collaborated last summer on a track called "Shelter." (7 p.m. Coachella Stage)

SUNDAY: Justice

This French duo’s first album was hailed as a “killer party record” by the A.V. Club and ended the year, 2007, on critics’ best-of lists at both Pitchfork and Blender. won a Grammy for their remix of the MGMT song “Electric Feel” in 2009. A second album arrived in 2011, the A.V. Club responding with “What ‘Audio, Video, Disco’ does best is show off what a pair of good producers can really do-namely, simplifying technical musicianship into head-throbbing dance music.” And last year’s “Woman” definitely” kept the party raging with plenty of highlights sure to have the club kids dancing up a dust storm. (9:55 Outdoor Theatre)

SUNDAY: Devendra Banhart

Listening to Banhart's latest effort made me think of Donovan – it's all in the trembling vocal. Anyhow, thinking of Donovan got me to thinking about the time I was talking to Donovan and decided to ask if he felt a connection to Banhart. "Yeah, yeah, yeah," he said. "I went to see him when he came to Ireland. And it was very cool. There's very much a lot of gypsy stuff in Devendra, just like me. I walk out there, the light comes up, and then I play guitar (makes guitar noise), and then when I sing, I'm actually looking at the audience going, 'I'm in town. I've just arrived.' Devendra does it, too." Getting back to Banhart's latest album, "Ape in Pink Marble" is an excellent addition to the catalog that plays to all the strengths he's shown along the way. As Magnet summed it up, "The fantasy and the fantastic continue, and his soft sculptural Dadaist lyrical sense of romance will always go with DevBan's trembling, lilting melodies like cheese and chocolate." (4:55 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

SUNDAY: Future Islands

These Baltimore synth-pop revivalists have one of modern music’s most distinctive vocalists in Samuel T. Herring, who enunciates like David Bowie with a diction coach. And it suits the drama of their music. They’re playing Coachella a week after hitting the streets with “The Far Field,” to which the A.V. Club responded, “The raw passion of Future Island’s past work still dominates, but with more complexity in the arrangements, and more push and pull in the ongoing dialogue between the voice and the instruments behind it.” (6:10 p.m. Outdoor Theatre)

SUNDAY: New Order

These guys are proper legends, formed in 1980 by three Joy Division members – Bernard Sumner, Stephen Morris and Peter Hook – after the suicide of singer Ian Curtis. Hook is no longer a member, having left in 2007 over personal conflicts. But three members of the current lineup – Sumner, Morris and Gillian Gilbert – have been on board since their first album, “Movement.” Filtering their post-punk through electronic music they discovered on the New York club scene, they became a hugely influential – and popular – presence on the ‘80s music scene. “Blue Monday” holds the distinction of being the biggest-selling 12-inch single of all time. (10:20 p.m. Mojave)

SUNDAY: Kaytranada

Born in Haiti and raised in Montreal, this Canadian DJ/producer made the rounds of critic's year-end lists last year with "99.9%." And with good reason. The album finds his effortlessly offsetting his more experimental urges with serious pop sensibilities, often in the course of one amazing track, from an R&B jam as contagious as "Together" to the hip-hop soul of "Drive Me Crazy" with Vic Mensa. As HipHopDX summed it up, "He seems to have complete control over the proverbial dance floor, switching up tempos to match the crowd’s mood throughout the 15-track album; this prevents 99.9% from feeling bloated and is yet another reason Kaytranada’s debut album is a resounding success." (5:45 p.m. Sahara)

SUNDAY: Tove Lo

This soulful Swedish electro-pop diva is touring an album titled “Lady Wood,” which earned a rave from Entertainment Weekly, whose critic sized it up with “Lo sounds as if she’s in the throes of a quarter-life crisis” while declaring the singer “a fearless outsider in pop music—the Janis Ian in a cafeteria full of Regina Georges.” Lo first grabbed the U.S. spotlight with a five-times-platinum breakthrough called “Habits (Stay High)” in 2014, following through with two more huge hit singles – the double-platinum “Talking Body” and last year’s “Cool Girl.” (7:55 p.m. Mojave)

SUNDAY: Skepta

His “Konnichiwa” was the U.K. grime scene’s breakthrough moment, winning the Mercury Prize for 2016, the same year Skepta won a BET Award for Best International Act: UK. NME declared “Konnichiwa” a “landmark in British street music, a record good enough to take on the world without having to compromise one inch in the process." (3:20 p.m. Sahara)

SUNDAY: Kehlani

This 21-year-old R&B star made it to the finals on "America's Got Talent" with her old group, Poplyfe, in 2014 and was nominated for a Grammy in 2016 (a Best Urban Contemporary Album nod for the mixtape "You Should Be Here"). "SweetSexySavage," her first proper studio album, topped the R&B charts earlier this year with Spin declaring it "a distinctly contemporary album that is in conversation with trendy, critically acclaimed R&B." Her best-known tracks are R&B hits "CRZY" and "Gangsta," the second of which is from the "Suicide Squad" soundtrack. (9:05 p.m. Mojave)

WHY YOU NEED TO ALWAYS READ THE SMALL PRINT

Coachella posters are designed so that the big, high-profile artists get the big type, and the up-and-coming and still-haven’t-gotten-there-yet-after-decades-of-trying artists get the small type at the bottom. People tend to focus on the names in big type. But oftentimes the artists at the bottom of the poster are the more exciting option. Here’s are my picks for each day of the festival.

FRIDAY: Sampha

This British singer-songwriter has worked with Drake ("Too Much"), Solange ("Don't Touch My Hair") and Kanye West ("Saint Pablo"). But never mind the guest spots: He's playing Coachella on the strength of "Process," a deeply emotional full-length debut whose highlights range from an achingly beautiful opening track called "Plastic 100º C" to the trembling vulnerability he displays on the gospel-flavored "No One Knows Me (Like the Piano)," a sentence that ends with "in my mother's home." As the Skinny noted, "Process is an exercise in catharsis, a deep breathe in that lays Sampha’s soul bare through gorgeous vignettes of his life. He worries, he regrets, he aches. He’s human." Still on the fence? You should know that the A.V. Club called it "the best R&B debut since FKA Twigs’ 'LP1.'" (4:20 p.m.)

FRIDAY: Lemon Twigs

The Lemon Twigs' "Do Hollywood" takes all the oddest, most outrageous elements of '60s pop and throws them in a blender to create its own intoxicating pop confection. There are echoes of the Kinks at their most whimsical. But it's the Kinks of "She's Bought a Hat Like Princess Marina," not "Waterloo Sunset." I would not be shocked to learn that the Twigs view "Winchester Cathedral" as some kind of overlooked classic. And I mean that in a good way. Under the Radar writes, "With one foot in the present and one foot in the past, the Lemon Twigs have produced one of the most striking, individual, and colorful debuts of the year." And I'd agree with nearly every point that writer makes, but I'm not hearing one foot in the present, which is fine. There's nothing they could borrow from the present that would make their music any more enjoyable than it already is. (2:30 p.m.)

FRIDAY: D.R.A.M.

Last year, the German-born rapper from Hampton, Virginia, whose stage name is an acronym for Does Real Ass Music, did his best to make the Billboard Hot 100 safe for real ass music with the four-times-platinum triumph that was "Broccoli." That song, with an assist from Lil Yachty, peaked at No. 5. And the album from which it was taken, "Big Baby D.R.A.M.," went well beyond the promise of its greatest hit in the process of making its way through such obvious highlights as the '70s funk vibe of "Misunderstood," the Erykah Badu-assisted "Wifi" and the instantly infectious "Cash Machine." The 405 says, "Unlike countless hip-hop albums that feel slapped together to fit in the artist's favorites alongside the label's, flow unconsidered, each moment of 'Big Baby' feels earned." (12:10 a.m.)

FRIDAY: Tacocat

These Seattle garage-punk revivalists have been building a buzz since the release three years ago of “NVM,” an album produced by the great Conrad Uno (Young Fresh Fellows, Mudhoney, etc), whose title appeared to be a fairly brilliant reference to Nirvana’s “Nevermind.” Last year brought yet another reason not to miss this show, with an album packed with effervescent pop hooks titled “Lost Time.” It opens with a really catchy “X-Files” tribute titled “Dana Katherine Scully” and makes its way through equally contagious songs about hating the weekend, menstruation and creepy dudes both on and off the Internet. As the reviewer at Record Collector was right on the money to call it, it’s “a joyful, spirited album that also stands to teach whoever listens to it some vital life lessons.” (4:55 p.m.)

FRIDAY: Stormzy

The U.K. grime sensation is touring the States in support of a full-length debut titled "Gang Signs & Prayer," which topped the U.K. album chart in February, the first grime album ever to accomplish that. As DIY Magazine raved, "If Skepta’s ‘Konnichiwa’ was grime’s breakthrough, 'Gang Signs & Prayer' is its blockbuster — an all-encompassing ride through human experience that’ll stand tall for decades." He's been working toward this moment for a few years, having won Best Grime Act at the 2014 and 2015 MOBO Awards as well as being named an artist to look out for in the BBC's influential Sound of 2015 list. He also topped the UK rap and indie charts with the new album's lead single "Big For Your Boots," which made our playlist of best February singles, where I noted, "It sounds like a hit, from the opening hook, in which the rapper warns that 'You’re getting way too big for your boots' before putting a spin on the words with a defiant 'You’re never too big for the boot / I’ve got the big size 12s on my feet / Your face ain’t big for my boot.'" (3 p.m.)

FRIDAY: Floorplan

Fans of minimalist techno can't afford to miss this set by DJ Robert Hood, who brought home raves in 2016 for "Victorious," the second album he's released as Floorplan, which sounds like a rave breaking out a tent revival meeting at times. As Resident Adviser summed it up: "The second Floorplan album feels triumphant enough to bear the title Victorious. It's a stellar follow-up to Paradise, an album that brought even more followers to Hood's flock and helped make him a feel-good festival mainstay. The record is also proof that you don't need to constantly reinvent yourself to stay relevant. Though Floorplan's details and production values have changed since the project debuted in 1996, its nuts and bolts haven't. Hood is still the master of the minimalist dance track — whether he's making dark, loopy beats or life-affirming anthems." (5 p.m.)

FRIDAY: Tennis

Patrick Riley and Alaina Moore of Tennis first earned a buzz for "Cape Dory," a concept album about the couple's sailing trip (on which you'd swear they listened to nothing but the music of the early '60s). And they managed to update their sound without abandoning their charm by the time a third album, called “Ritual in Repeat,” hit the streets in 2014, with production by Patrick Carney of the Black Keys, Jim Eno of Spoon and Richard Swift. As Magnet noted, “Tennis dances easily into the present with an album that pines for more for modern connection than campy reinventions of someone else's love.” And if this year's "Yours Conditionally" feels like classic Tennis, it may have a little to do with the fact that Moore and Riley wrote it on a five-month sailing trip around the Sea of Cortez. As musicOMH responded, "'Yours Conditionally' is indeed a restoration of the loose-fitting, blissful, summertime tunes that brought Tennis to the attention of internet music sites everywhere. The opening line of the album is 'I’ll wipe your cares away,' and it couldn’t be more apt." (3:10 p.m.)

FRIDAY: Preservation Hall Jazz Band

Taking their name from Preservation Hall, the legendary music venue they call home in New Orleans' French Quarter, they're known for performing traditional New Orleans jazz, which they've been doing through various lineup changes since the early '60s. Their mainstream profile got a boost in 2013 when they joined the Black Keys in one of the more exciting Grammy Awards performances in recent memory. Their latest album, "That's It!," was produced by Jim James of My Morning Jacket. Released in 2013, it marked their 50th anniversary with their first collection of all original material. (3:30 p.m.)

FRIDAY: King Gizzard & the Lizard Wizard

They’ve promised no fewer than five full-length albums before the year is out. And if you’re thinking, “What are they, high?” well, the answer is almost undoubtedly “so high you wouldn’t believe it.” If you’re into the psychedelic side of garage-rock at all, you’d do well to check out the first of those five albums, “Flying Microtonal Banana,” on which their trippy fuzz guitars are flavored with touches as unusual as flute and Turkish horns. The end result is, as DIY noted, rich, imaginative, and more than a little strange. (4:10 p.m.)

FRIDAY: Guided By Voices

Is Robert Pollard of Guided by Voices the first artist in the history of rock and roll to have released 100 albums, a feat he recently accomplished by virtue of GBV's "August By Cake?" You'd have to think so, right? I mean, Bob Dylan's made a lot of albums. He's at 39 studio albums. If you count the Traveling Wilburys. And Pollard has only been doing this since "Forever Since Breakfast" arrived in 1986. As for the new one? It sounds like classic GBV, a mix of scappy pop songs bashed out with the reckless abandon of a Who fan who doesn't see sweating the details as a good thing and odd psychedelic departures. Like Bennie and the Jets before them, oh, but they're weird and they're wonderful. In addition to Pollard, the album features two GBV veterans -- Doug Gillard and Kevin March -- as well as new arrivals Bobby Bare Jr and Mark Shue. And get this, it's a two-record set.

SATURDAY: Car Seat Headrest

Azcentral.com was among the several billion publications that included Car Sear Headrest of their year-end album lists for 2016. As I wrote at the time: The most compelling evidence I heard all year that rock and roll is here to stay? The guitars on Car Seat Headrest’s latest album, an exhilarating ride that gets off to an unassuming start when a female voice sheepishly introduces them with “What’s up, guys? You are now listening to … uh, Car Seat Headrest.” She sounds like she has no idea who they are. And by the time the toms come crashing in to meet that opening guitar riff, it’s already clear that that would be her loss, not theirs. ... If you grew up on Pavement and lived through the turn-of-the-century rock revival before deciding you wanted to write an album that felt like you’d just woken up hungover in the CBGB men’s room after passing out to Television? You’d do well to hope it sounded half as good as this." (4:15 p.m.)

SATURDAY: Thundercat

LA bassist Stephen Bruner may be best known for his work with Flying Lotus. In a perfect world, “Drunk” would change all that – which I probably said in 2013, when he released “Apocalypse,” as well. The man’s musical chops are a given, as always. He’s a monster on the bass with few if any equals in that magic place where jazz and funk collide. On “Drunk,” a recently released fourth album boasting guest spots by Kendrick Lamar, Kenny Loggins and Michael McDonald (on the same track!) and Pharrell, he’s created a suitably intoxicating soundtrack to a concept album exploring the common side effects of what Ray Davies once called "demon alcohol," from the dizzying speed bass of the jazz-funk instrumental “Uh Uh” to the yacht-rock gold that is the Loggins-McDonald jam, “Show Me the Way.” And to be clear, as musicOMH was right to note: While his work references styles of music (smooth jazz, soft-rock, prog) that haven’t always been considered fashionable, he’s always stressed that it comes from a place of honesty and love; there’s playfulness and humor, but it’s never tongue-in-cheek. (5:30 p.m.)

SATURDAY: Swet Shop Boys

Heems of Das Racist and British Pakistani actor Riz Ahmed (as seen in HBO’s “The Night Of”) released one of the more intriguing hip-hop albums of 2016, "Cashmere," an intensely political party record that filters western hip-hop through the sounds of Bollywood and qawwali music. On "T5," the opening track, they take aim at the systemic racism people of color are forced to endure as they travel the world, with a taunting chorus hook of “Oh no, we’re in trouble / TSA always wanna burst my bubble / Always get a random check when I rock this stubble.” And the tracks that follow are every bit as thought-provoking, taking aim at heavy issues without feeling heavy-handed. "To Westerners, cashmere is a luxury textile," Pitchfork noted. "To South Asians, it’s the site of a violent territorial dispute between India and Pakistan that hinges on questions of identity. It’s a perfect title for a project that blurs the lines between all of these perspectives, that stunts as much as it elucidates, and which ties up all of these messy ideas into a refreshingly expansive vision of South Asian identity." Also, that's one brilliant band name. (1 p.m.)

SATURDAY: Mitski

The buzz on this New York-based indie sensation began in 2014 with the release of "Bury Me at Makeout Creek," with Pitchfork rightly noting that her "broad, tremulous vocals and sly humor recall Angel Olsen while the equal split between unencumbered acoustic pining and pummeling, mid-fi indie rock respectively aligns her with labelmates Frankie Cosmos and LVL UP." She really hit her stride, though, on "Puberty 2." Released last year, the album finds her growing as an artist and a singer, expanding the scope or her sound without abandoning the qualities that made her so appealing in the first place. It also featured one of 2016's most beguiling singles, "Your Best American Girl," a delicate whisper of a song that kicks in on the chorus with chugging distorted guitars and feedback like some great lost relic from the golden age of “This is how Nirvana did it.” (2:45 p.m.)

SATURDAY: Downtown Boys

We all know punk’s not dead, but it can’t hurt to prove it as conclusively as these Rhode Island upstarts (led by Victoria Ruiz on vocals) have done with conviction to spare on “Somos Chula (No Somos Pendejas),” which translates, I am told, as “We are beautiful (We are not stupid).” When they shared the track on Facebook, they called it “a declaration of one's ability to decolonize one's mind, and the importance of fearlessly unlearning the ways white supremacy conditions people to think and exist.” It’s the sort sentiment that was made to be expressed in the universal language of punk. And they express it well, as they did on a 2015 debut hailed in NME as “a joyous surge of drums, guitars, wild brass and potent Spanish-English vocals.” (3:10 p.m.)

SATURDAY: Chicano Batman

These LA rockers filter old-school funk and soul through elements of psychedelic pop and Tropicalia for an end result that couldn't feel more timeless than it does on their new album "Freedom is Free." It's as though they'd been assigned to write the soundtrack to an LA cop show in the very early '70s. There's even a hint of "Shaft" guitar on "Angel Child." And yet, as the reviewer at PopMatters notes, "The thing is, it’s brand new music. But it sounds like it wasn’t recorded within 100 miles of a laptop." The lyrics, on the other hand, are firmly rooted in the harsh realities of American life in the 21st century. The title track, for instance, is their answer song to bumper sticker claiming "Freedom Isn't Free." As Bardo Martinez testifies, "You got your guns up on display / But you can't control how I feel no way / 'Cause freedom is free." (4:30 p.m.)

SATURDAY: Classixx

Last year, the electronic duo of Michael David and Tyler Blake released a second album called “Faraway Reach,” which featured guest appearances from How To Dress Well, Isles, Nonku, Panama, Passion Pit and T-Pain. Clash Music declared it “a happy place full of group hugs and big shiny grooves,” while Mixmag said it “bursts with sun-soaked vibes.” They’re both right, as it turns out. (12 a.m.)

SATURDAY: Blossoms

These Brits spend the bulk of their self-titled album recalling the pop acts of the '80s who did their best to be filed under New Wave. But not in a bad way. There are dozens of young artists doing their damnedest to channel the edgier post-punk side of that same era. This is for the pop kids. As Clash Music noted, "Blossoms have produced an album of perfectly structured songs accompanied by strong lyrics that tell many tales to the large cult they seem to have already acquired." (1:10 p.m.)

SUNDAY: Whitney

These guys made my Albums of the Year list for 2016. As I wrote at the time, "This is a stunning collection of deeply soulful chamber pop, its richly textured soft-rock sensibilities topped by Julien Ehrlich’s aching upper register. The man wears his heart on his sleeve with the vulnerability of Neil Young on a rainy day. And it serves him well, from the opening line of the opening track, where the orchestrated intro dissolves into Ehrlich accompanied only by the strum of acoustic guitar as he sets the tone with “I left drinking on the city train” to the wounded majesty of “Polly,” the album’s emotional core." Ehrlich comes to this project, along with guitarist Max Kakacek, from Smith Westerns (who, it should be noted, sounded nothing like this). (3:45 p.m.)

SUNDAY: Hinds

These young Spanish women are touring the States in continued support of a charming debut titled “Leave Me Alone,” which would be difficult to leave alone because the songs are too contagious to just walk away and move on to the next young hopefuls. Guitar-playing vocalist Ana Perrote and Carlotta Cosials sing with personality to spare, their voices intertwining without any sense that they even tried to match each other’s phrasing. It’s the kind of sloppy that’s too often missing – or forced – when people try to make garage-rock records. This is imperfectly imperfect and blessed with indelible pop hooks. No wonder the Skinny declared it “the peppiest, jauntiest, most charismatic debut you’ll likely find in the next 12 months.” It sounds like people having fun with rock and roll. And what could be more fun than that? (3:05 p.m.)

search_result.text:
David Byrne is playing Mesa in a month that also features Valley concerts by Odesza and Jake Owens.

Here's a look at those and other highlights of the month in Valley concerts.

4/19: Highly Suspect

These Massachusetts rockers arrived at an intriguing cocktail of radio-ready alternative-rock and headbanging classic-rock echoes on “The Boy Who Died Wolf,” which Mojo wrongfully dismissed with “may alarm those who recall grunge and nu metal.”

That doesn’t account for the post-punk revival of the exhilarating “Look Alive, Stay Alive,” where Johnny Stevens sneers the lyrics with attitude closer in spirit to punk than nu-metal or post-Nirvana grunge or the inflammatory anti-racist politics of “Viper Strike.”

Details: 8 p.m. Thursday, April 19. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $30. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/19: David Byrne

He fronted Talking Heads, whose impact on the culture of the 1980s was profound and undeniable while barely hinting at the impact they'd go on to have on future generations, thanks in large part to the revolutionary vision of their fearless leader.

The show is a mix of new material from the excellent "American Utopia" and "many others that will, I assume, be familiar." He also says "This is the most ambitious show I’ve done since the shows that were filmed for ‘Stop Making Sense,’ so fingers crossed.”

Details: 7:30 p.m. Thursday, April19. Mesa Arts Center, 1 E. Main St. SOLD OUT. 480-644-6500, mesaartscenter.com.

4/19: Dayme Arocena

Arocena’s talent was recognized during the Havana Cultura Mix project, which saw French-born English DJ/producer Gilles Peterson mentoring producers from around the world to record in Cuba with local musicians.

Her latest album, "Cubafonia," is a soulful mix of Latin music, jazz and R&B. NPR called it "a major statement on the progress of Daymé Arocena as an artist for the ages" while the Guardian went even further, naming Arocena "Cuba's finest vocalist."

Details: 7:30 p.m. Thursday, April 19. Musical Instrument Museum, 4725 E. Mayo Blvd., Phoenix. $33.50-$38.50. 480-478-6000, themim.org.

4/20: UFEST

Five Finger Death Punch headline this year's KUPD festival with Jonathan Davis of Korn, and Sevendust also performing.

Having taken one of modern metal’s greatest band names from a fatal blow in Quentin Tarantino’s “Kill Bill: Vol. 2,” Five Finger Death Punch have sent four singles to the top of Billboard's Mainstream Rock charts, from "Coming Down" to "Wash It All Away."

Details: 3 p.m. Friday, April 20. Venue TBA. $49; $125 VIP. ticketmaster.com.

4/20: Odesza

Phoenix got an early look at Odesza's A Moment Apart Tour when they headlined Lost Lake Festival. "This was, by far, the weekend's most visually stunning performance," I wrote at the time. "It was breathtaking, really, which suited the vibe of the music."

Their ethereal vocals and atmospheric textures were complemented by a gorgeous light show with colorful lasers slicing through the desert sky. And when they did fall back on thumping house beats? That was pretty special, too.

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, April 20. The Park at Wild Horse Pass, Wild Horse Pass Road, Chandler. $49. relentlessbeats.com.

4/20: Cradle of Filth

These English metal veterans are touring on “Cryptoriana – The Seductiveness of Decay,” a symphonic adrenaline rush with haunting gothic overtones and operatic touches with plenty of throat-shredding grunts and shrieks.

Kerrang! praised the album for have “created a gothic horror that makes Mary Shelley's 'Frankenstein' look like 'The Emoji Movie.'” There's also plenty of fleet-fingered dual-guitar harmonies from the Iron Maiden school of lead guitar.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Friday, April 20. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $32-$47. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/21: Vance Joy

The Australian singer-songwriter is touring a sophomore album called “Nation of Two.” Entertainment Weekly loved it, writing, “Joy focused on crafting piercing vignettes of young love and emotional restlessness --- and the results absolutely thrill.”

This album follows a platinum debut, “Dream Your Life Away,” which spawned the singer’s mainstream breakthrough, a quadruple-platinum smash called “Riptide" that topped both the rock and alternative radio charts.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Saturday, April 21. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $29.50-$42.50. livenation.com.

4/22: Rain: A Tribute to the Beatles

They’re celebrating the 50th Anniversary of “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band,” an anniversary that actually occurred last year, by playing the entire album live.

The Beatles never toured on "Sgt. Pepper," having come in off the road in 1966 to focus on pushing the boundaries of popular music by playing the studio like an instrument.

That may be why this tribute show has been hailed by the Associated Press as “the next best thing to seeing The Beatles!”

Poor Paul McCartney. He gets no respect.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Sunday, April 22. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $38.50-$143.72. livenation.com.

4/23: 5 Seconds of Summer

These Australian heartthrobs topped the U.S. charts with a self-titled album of spirited pop-punk songs in 2014, the same year they opened a One Direction tour. Their hits include "She Looks So Perfect," "Don't Stop," "Amnesia" and "Good Girls."

In their second cover story on the boys, Billboard noted, “5SOS is an anomaly in 2015: a Generation Z guitar band that sells records." Alternative Press and Kerrang! both raved about their latest album, which doesn't happen often to teen idols.

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, April 23. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $29.50-$120. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/23: Alvvays

These Toronto-based dream-pop sensations, led by Molly Rankin, are touring in support of last year's "Antisocialites," an infectious sophomore effort that made the round of critics' year-end lists, from NPR to Gorilla vs Bear, Uproxx, Stereogum and Noisey.

NPR said "The record is possibly the most complete cover-to-cover listen of 2017, as the band seamlessly switches gears from dreamy pop to jangly rock and back again." And Rolling Stone praised its "fuzzy-guitar beauty and shoegazing romanticism."

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, April 23. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. SOLD OUT. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/24: Judas Priest

The metal legends' double-platinum U.S. breakthrough, "Screaming for Vengeance," hit the streets in 1982 and spawned their best-known song here in the States, "You've Got Another Thing Comin'."

This tour is in support of last year's "Firepower," which Kerrang! calls "as sharp as can be, as powerful as an atom bomb, and exactly the sort of thrilling metal adventure you want from them." An atom bomb is pretty powerful, so don't miss out.

Details: 7 p.m. Tuesday, April 24. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $73.75-$563. livenation.com.

4/24: The Moondoggies

It's been a while since their latest release, "Adios, I'm a Ghost," but it still makes a pretty calling card, blurring the lines between folk-rock, alternative country, '60s soul and psychedelic pop with melodies that stick.

Consequence of Sound invoked Fleet Foxes, Band of Horses and My Morning Jacket in reviewing "Adios," and these folkies from Washington state could speak to fans of any of those bands on tour, but they might have to tone it down a bit for that Fleet Foxes crowd.

Details: 8 p.m. Tuesday, April 24. Rebel Lounge, 2303 E. Indian School Road, Phoenix. $12; $10 in advance. 602-296-7013, therebellounge.com.

4/27: Midland

Led by Arizona native Mark Wystrach, Midland's debut album, "On The Rocks," was strong enough to take this neo-traditionalist country trio from Texas honky tonks to sharing a stadium bill with Kenny Chesney for 55,000 people.

The album also spawned their first chart-topping country single, "Drinkin' Problem." Taking their name from a Dwight Yoakam lyric, they've describe their sound as “…if George Strait and the Eagles just went and had a really wild debaucherous weekend."

Details: 7 p.m. Friday, April 27. Celebrity Theatre, 440 N. 32nd St., Phoenix. $25-$35. 602-267-1600, celebritytheatre.com.

4/27: Colter Wall

It takes a rare sort of talent to pull off a folk song containing the line “With my guitar and my buck knife, thumbin’ down Woody Guthrie’s street” with the conviction such a thought requires. And Wall is just that kind of talent.

By the time he hits you with that lyric in “Transcendent Ramblin’ Railroad Blues” nine songs deep on his self-titled debut, he’s long since asserted himself as the real deal, as authentically folk as a new Bob Dylan with a voice as deep as Johnny Cash.

Details: 8:30 p.m. Friday, April 27. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $18; $15 in advance. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/28: Wet Electric

America’s largest pool party returns to Big Surf Waterpark.

Even the people at Relentless Beats consider this the most fun festival they do, with artists and DJs performing on a massive floating stage in the middle of a 2.5-million-gallon wave pool, with water slides, luxury cabanas, bars and more.

Adventure Club, Bro Safari, Crizzly, Dr Fresch, Loud Luxury, Sevenn, JPhlip, SNBRN, Codes, Lavelle Dupree, Shift K3y and Worthy b2b Option 4 are scheduled to perform.

Details: 12 p.m. Saturday, April 28. Big Surf, 1500 N. McClintock Dr., Tempe. $49; VIP passes and packages start at $99 plus fees. Lockers are available for rent at $15 plus fees. www.wet-electric.com.

4/28: Jake Owen

The Academy of Country Music's pick for Top New Male Vocalist in 2009, his best-known hits include three No. 1 appearances on Billboard’s country songs chart – “Barefoot Blue Jean Night,” “Alone With You” and “Beachin’.”

Owen headlined Country Thunder Arizona in 2016, inspiring one massive singalong after another, from his own hits to Van Halen's "Jump" and Drake's "Hold On, We're Going Home." He headlines Encanterra's Good Life Festival.

Details: 2 p.m. Saturday, April 28. 36460 N Encanterra Dr., San Tan Valley. $45-$95. thegoodlifefest.com.

4/28: Blackalicious

With Gift of Gab on the tongue-twisting lyrics and DJ Chief Xcel on the beats and samples, this alt-rap duo may be best remembered for triumphs as timeless as “Alphabet Aerobics,” “A to G” and “Making Progress.”

When they returned to something close to active duty in 2015 with “Imani Vol. 1,” their first new album since 2005’s acclaimed “The Craft,” they pulled in raves from the A.V. Club, Q Magazine and the Chicago Tribune.

Details: 9 p.m. Saturday, April 28. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $5-$9. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/28: The Weight Band

The Weight Band started in the Woodstock barn of Levon Helm when Jim Weider and Randy Ciarlante – who both played with Helm in the Band – performed Songs of the Band with Band founder Garth Hudson alongside Jimmy Vivino and Byron Isaacs.

After four years of the songs of the Band on the road, they've recorded an album of original material aimed at capturing the musical tradition embodied on such classic albums as "The Basement Tapes" and "Music From Big Pink."

Details: 6 p.m. Saturday, April 28. Rhythm Room, 1019 E. Indian School Road, Phoenix. $32; $26 in advance. 602-265-4842, rhythmroom.com.

4/28: The Distillers

It's been 15 years since the Distillers hit us with their third and final album, "Coral Fang," imploding three years later with singer Brody Dalle, among the more ferocious female voices on the punk scene, forming Spinnerette with lead guitarist Tony Bevilacqua.

That makes this reunion tour a pretty big event in certain circle pits and Phoenix is the third date on the tour. There's talk of new material but chances are they'll be blowing the dust off plenty of the songs that made you love them in the first place.

Details: 8 p.m. Saturday, April 28. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. SOLD OUT. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/29: Sum 41

These Canadian pop-punk sensations topped the Billboard modern-rock charts with a breakthrough single titled "Fat Lip," which helped make their debut, "All Killer No Filler," the platinum triumph it became.

Subsequent hits include "In Too Deep," "Still Waiting," "The Hell Song" and "We're All to Blame." They're touring in support of "13 Voices," a hard-rocking effort to which Kerrang! responded, "Its execution is what makes it Sum 41's finest offering to date."

Details: 8 p.m. Sunday, April 29. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $27-$196. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/29: Sage Francis

The underground hip-hop sensation has been keeping quiet since 2014’s "Copper Gone," which RapReviews found to be "among his best work," adding that "he raps with the passion and fury of a rapper on his first LP."

But this Epic Beard Men with B. Dolan is apparently tied to a collaboration due some time this year.

Details: 7 p.m. Sunday, April 29. Pub Rock, 8005 E. Roosevelt St., Phoenix. $20; $17 in advance. 480-945-4985, pubrocklive.com.

PAST EVENTS

4/2: OMD

These synth-pop legends first tasted success in the States on the dancefloor with a 1980 breakthrough called “Enola Gay.” But it was five more years before they hit the U.S. pop charts with the melancholy breakup ballad “So In Love.”

Their best-known U.S. hit remains the lush, romantic “If You Leave,” which was written specifically for the final scene of “Pretty in Pink.” That's not to say this show is pure nostalgia. Not if last year's excellent "The Punishment of Luxury" is any indication.

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, April 2. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $28-$48. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/2: Brian Fallon & the Howling Weather

He rose to fame as the Springsteenesque voice at the helm of New Jersey punks the Gaslight Anthem. In 2015, he went solo with "Painkillers," an album that effortlessly lived up to the promise of the Gaslight Anthem's most inspired work.

This tour is in support of this year's model, "Sleepwalkers," an album fueled by Fallon's interest in the Vox Continental, the distinctive organ used by such iconic artists as the Animals and Elvis Costello and the Attractions.

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, April 2. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $25. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/3: Knuckle Puck

These Chicago-based emo sensations are heading to Mesa in support of "Shapeshifter," a second album that makes the most of the urgency singer Joe Taylor invests in conveying the pain and pathos of his lyrics.

Rock Sound says, "Front to back, start to finish, this is pop-punk for those who have lived, loved and lost and aren’t afraid to contemplate the fact that maybe, just maybe, it isn’t going to be their weekend or their year."

Details: 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, April 3. Nile Theater, 105 W. Main St., Mesa. $18. 480-559-5859, niletheater.com.

4/3: Titus Andronicus

Taking their name from the title of William Shakespeare's most violent tragedy, these Jersey boys uncork their epic, existential anthems like a half-mad Springsteen raised on Irish punk and pounding Guinness like there's no tomorrow.

"The Airing of Grievances" was a brilliant first move, "The Monitor" proved even more intense, and by the time they got to "Local Business," they'd tightened things up without losing their edge or urgency.

Six years and two albums down the road from "Local Business," they're heading our way in support of "A Productive Cough," an album that crashes the gate with a desperate eight-minute fever-dream and includes a rewrite of Bob Dylan's "Like a Rolling Stone."

Details: 8 p.m. Tuesday, April 3. Valley Bar, 130 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. $18; $15 in advance. 602-368-3121, valleybarphx.com.

4/4: Ty Dolla $ign

This West Coast rapper broke through after signing to Taylor Gang Records with 2013's "Paranoid," following through with the triple-platinum smash "Or Nah" from that same "Beach House" EP. Other hits include "Blase," "Wavy" and "Sucker for Pain."

Tiny Mix Tapes called his latest effort, "Beach House 3" a "strong, strong effort: universally pleasant in the same way as its antecedents, but given a thorough sonic update so as to keep pace with modernity."

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, April 4. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $29.50-$44.50. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/4: Shelby Lynne

The Alabama singer-songwriter has had an unconventional career, down to winning the Grammy for best new artist after releasing a full six albums. Her output is diverse, ranging from a well-received Dusty Springfield tribute to a Western swing disc and a holiday collection.

Details: 7 p.m. Wednesday, April 4. Musical Instrument Museum, 4725 E. Mayo Blvd., Phoenix. $43.50-$53.50. 480-478-6000, themim.org.

4/5: Scott H. Biram

A swampy, stompy one-man blues explosion based in Austin, Biram likes to call his blend of backwoods blues and porch-front country "lo-fi mojo." He even titled his third album that. And he's still lo-fi after all these years.

On 2011's classic "Bad Ingredients," Biram memorably hollered "I killed a chicken last night" with conviction. And his new album, "The Bad Testament," proves time has yet to dull the man's edges, a point made abundantly clear on "Trainwrecker."

Details: 7:p.m. Thursday, April 4. Rhythm Room, 1019 E. Indian School Road, Phoenix. $15; $12 in advance. 602-265-4842, rhythmroom.com.

4/5-8: Country Thunder

Luke Bryan, Jason Aldean, Toby Keith and Cole Swindell headline this year's Country Thunder Arizona lineup. Other acts include Brett Young, Tracy Lawrence, Big & Rich, Lindsay Ell, Cody Johnson, Neal McCoy, Lukas Nelson and Bryan White.

“We are so proud to create the ultimate festival experience for our fans in Arizona,” says Country Thunder CEO Troy Vollhoffer, who calls this a "dream lineup.”

TIPS:Country Thunder camping rules and what to know before you go

MORE:What to bring to Country Thunder

Details: Thursday, April 5-Sunday, April 8. 20585 E. Price Station, Florence. $75-$150 a day; $190 weekend pass. countrythunder.com.

4/6: Gloria Trevi Vs. Alejandra Guzman

It's being billed as “the most significant Latin tour of the decade” and was nominated as the Latin Tour Of The Year by Pollstar magazine. It was on this tour that they became the first Mexican women to sell out Staples Center for two consecutive nights.

The 'Vs'. in the title of the tour is a reference to "Versus," a 2017 release that became the first collaborative album by two women to top the Billboard Latin album charts.

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, April 6. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $59.50-$500. livenation.com.

4/6: Dick Dale

There's a reason he could get away with "King of the Surf Guitar" as a title for his second album back in 1963. He earned that badge. And this is long before his take on "Miserlou" helped make "Pulp Fiction" twice as bad-ass as it would've been without it.

As the Rolling Stone Album Guide sums up enduring impact, "With the release of his first single in 1961, 'Let's Go Trippin'," he created an entire genre, surf music, as well as one of the most unique and influential guitar styles in rock & roll history."

Also, if you're going, do not miss Grave Danger.

Details: 8:30 p.m. Friday, April 6. Rhythm Room, 1019 E. Indian School Road, Phoenix. $35-$40. 602-265-4842, rhythmroom.com.

4/6: Loma

A new project featuring Shearwater's Jonathan Meiburg with Emily Cross and Dan Duszynski of Cross Record, Loma arrive in support of a self-titled effort that places Cross' ethereal vocals front and center to haunting effect.

Q magazine says, "As intense as music can be, this record may be quiet but it isn't for the faint-hearted" while Dusted declared it "a melding of energies that is both fragilely beautiful and extraordinarily resilient."

Details: 7:30 p.m. Friday, April 6. Valley Bar, 130 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. $12; $10 in advance. 602-368-3121, valleybarphx.com.

4/7: Moses Sumney

Sumney's upper register is beyond ethereal, a breathtaking instrument he put to brilliant use on "Aromanticism," a debut that feels like the arrival of a major artist. Consequence of Sound declared it one of last year's "most emotionally therapeutic albums."

And it is, Sumney making his through such heartbreaking highlights as "Don't Bother Calling," "Lonely World" and the otherworldly soul of "Quarrel," a gorgeous production that feels as much like modern jazz as R&B.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Saturday, April 7. Musical Instrument Museum, 4725 E. Mayo Blvd., Phoenix. $35.50-$45.50. 480-478-6000, themim.org.

4/7-8: Phoenix Lights

The fourth annual Phoenix Lights Festival will be the first marquee event to take place at the Park at Wild Horse Pass, a venue built specifically to host Relentless Beats events without the sound and size restrictions that were often a hindrance at previous venues.

Diplo, Gucci Mane, Martin Garrix and Travis Scott headline, with Autograf, Bad Decisions, Beats Antique (DJ set), Chris Lake, Goldfish, Gramatik, Joyride, Kasbo, Kuuro, Melvv, Minnesota, Morgan Page, Oshi, Seven Lions and Zombo.

Additionally, Relentless Beats’ premiere house, techno and underground brand, RBDeep, will return to host a stage with performances by Bruno Furlan, Christoph, Eli & Fur, Huxley, Lee Foss, MK, Umek and Will Clarke.

Details: Noon, Saturday and Sunday, April 7-8. The Park at Wild Horse Pass, Wild Horse Pass Road, Chandler. $159-$179; $239-$249 VIP. relentlessbeats.com.

4/8: Crowder

The contemporary Christian musician's American Prodigal Tour 3.0 features live performances from "American Prodigal," his second album since the breakup of the David Crowder Band, with whom he won eight Dove Awards.

Both Crowder albums, "American Prodigal" and "Neon Steeple," topped the Billboard Christian album charts, as did his final four studio albums with the Crowder band.

Details: 7 p.m. Sunday, April 8. Grand Canyon University Arena, 3300 W. Camelback Road, Phoenix. $20-$75; $10 with GCU student ID. 602-639-8979, gcuarena.com.

4/9: Frankie Cosmos

The daughter of actors Kevin Kline and Phoebe Cates, Greta Kline began performing and releasing lo-fi indie-pop/anti-folk bedroom recordings as Ingrid Superstar before changing her alias to Frankie Cosmos.

An outrageously prolific artists, she arrives in support of an early contender for the upper reaches of my year-end album list, "Vessel," the delicate vulnerability of her delivery offset by just enough quirks to make her singing effortlessly stand out in a crowd.

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, April 9. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $18; $15 in advance. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/10: Turnover

It's not for nothing that DIY Magazine invoked the names of Real Estate and Beach House in trying to capture the summery breeze that blows through "Good Nature," their latest release.

It's an atmospheric daydream of a record. And as Pitchfork notes, their move to California may have seeped into the album's "warm embrace of the area’s soft-focus spirituality and the optimism of young, beautiful creatives without much to worry about."

Details: 8 p.m. Tuesday, April 10. The Pressroom, 441 W. Madison St., Phoenix. $19.99-$24. in advance. 602-396-7136, thepressroomaz.com.

4/11: Collective Soul at Arizona Bike Week

Since breaking through in 1993 with the rock anthem “Shine," they’ve sold more than 20 million records worldwide and continue to average more than one million Spotify streams per month.

And "Shine" was just the first of seven songs they sent to No. 1 on Billboard's mainstream rock chart, followed by "December," "The World I Know," "Where the River Flows," "Precious Declaration," "Listen" and "Heavy."

Details: 9 p.m. Wednesday, April 11. The RockYard at WestWorld of Scottsdale, 16601 N. Pima Road. $25 single-day admission; $58 weekend pass. azbikeweek.com.

4/11: Jungle

A modern soul collective formed by childhood friends Tom McFarland and Josh Lloyd-Watson in Shepherds Bush, London, they were shortlisted for the prestigious Mercury Prize in 2014 on the strength a very funky self-titled debut.

Mojo praised them for skillfully replicating "the sexy patinas of their varied influences" while DIY magazine praised them as "a spectacular live band."

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, April 11. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $25. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/11: Soccer Mommy

Twenty-year-old Nashville native Sophie Allison is touring on a full-length debut titled “Clean" that more than lives up to the promise of last year's "Collection" EP. As Pitchfork says, " 'Clean' is that much-cooler indie record Taylor once sang of."

It’s also a breathtaking sample of Allison's range, from the vulnerability of an opening track whose chorus is “I’m only what you wanted for a little while" to theresentment of a song that sets the tone with her demanding "I don't want to be you f--king dog."

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, April 11. Valley Bar, 130 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. $18; $15 in advance. 602-368-3121, valleybarphx.com.

4/12: Chevelle at Arizona Bike Week

These alt-metal veterans named their second album "Wonder What's Next" and then became the answer when three singles from that platinum breakthrough hit the mainstream-rock and modern-rock charts.

"The Red" and "Send the Pain Below" hit No. 1 on both charts. And they've topped the mainstream-rock charts four more times since then, with "Vitamin R (Leading Us Along)," "Face to the Floor," "Take Out the Gunman" and "Joyride (Omen)."

Details: 9 p.m. Thursday, April 12. The RockYard at WestWorld of Scottsdale, 16601 N. Pima Road. $25 single-day admission; $58 weekend pass. azbikeweek.com.

4/12: Doobie Brothers

Founding members Tom Johnston and Patrick Simmons are joined by longtime member John McFee on guitars,strings and vocals and Little Feat co-founder Bill Payne, who's played on many Doobie Brothers albums and tours.

Their latest album, “Southbound,” features new recordings of their greatest hits with guest appearances from some of country music’s biggest stars, from Blake Shelton to Zac Brown Band, Brad Paisley and Toby Keith.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Thursday, April 12. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $55-$349. livenation.com.

4/13: Shinedown at Arizona Bike Week

These Jacksonville rockers are headed to Bike Week less than a month before releasing their sixth album, "Attention Attention."

Their rock radio hits include "Save Me," "Devour," "Second Chance," "Sound of Madness," "The Crow & the Butterfly," "Diamond Eyes (Boom-lay, Boom-lay, Boom)," "Bully," "Unity," "Cut the Cord," "State of My Head" and "How Did You Love."

Details: 9 p.m. Friday, April 13. The RockYard at WestWorld of Scottsdale, 16601 N. Pima Road. $30 single-day admission; $58 weekend pass. azbikeweek.com.

4/13: King Krule

Archy Ivan Marshall is a 23-year-old from England who studied art at Brit School and whose music is a woozy blend of hip-hop, trip-hop, punk and jazz.

He's touring on "The Ooz," which made the Top 10 in Best of 2017 lists at Pitchfork, Vice and Clash, among others.

There are times, when he's shouting the lyrics like a drunk Joe Strummer, where it sounds like Damon Albarn remixing the Clash's "Sandinista!" to sound more like jazz.

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, April 13. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $25-$55. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

4/13: Alt-J

Best known in the U.S. for the singles “Breezeblocks,” “Tessellate,” “Left Hand Free” and “Every Other Freckle,” these British indie-rockers earned a Grammy nomination for 2014's “This Is All Yours.”

They're touring the States in support of "Relaxer," which Q and NME named to their year-end album lists. "It’s perhaps not what we might have expected from the 2012 Mercury Prize winners," NME concluded. "But it’s almost certainly what we needed."

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, April 13. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $53.50. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/14: ZZ Top at Arizona Bike Week

These Texas rockers took their place in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2004 on the strength of a career that evolved from the gut-bucket blues-rocking swagger of "La Grange" and "Tush" to the synthesized polish of their '80s MTV hits.

As the rock-hall website sizes up their legacy: "For many, ZZ Top have been the premiere party band on the planet. Certainly, they have been Texas' foremost cultural ambassadors."

Details: 9 p.m. April 11-15. The RockYard at WestWorld of Scottsdale, 16601 N. Pima Road. $30 single-day admission; $58 weekend pass. azbikeweek.com.

4/14: Kate Nash

This singer-actor-songwriter-musician won Best British Female Artist at the Brit Awards in 2008 on the strength of a breakthrough single called "Foundations," taken from a debut album, "Made of Bricks," that topped the U.K. charts.

A decade later, she's touring the States in support of "Yesterday was Forever," Drowned in Sound says, "Nash hasn't just tried to continue her legacy as one of the UK's most iconic, honest and innovative pop sensations… she has completely rewritten it."

Details: 8 p.m. Saturday, April 14. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $25; $20 in advance. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

4/15: Ha*Ash

Mexican-American sisters Hanna Nicole Pérez and Ashley Grace Pérez Mosa perform a mixture of Latin pop, rock, country and singer-songwriter music.

Their hits include: "Lo Aprendí de Ti," "Perdón Perdón," "Estés En Donde Estés," "Odio Amarte," "Te Quedaste," and "Amor a Medias."

Their latest album, "30 de Febrero," includes a guest appearance by Prince Royce.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Sunday, April 15. Comerica Theatre,– 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $49.50-$197. livenation.com.

4/15: Chromeo

These Canadian electro-funk sensations first made a name for themselves in 2004 with a debut called “She’s in Control” that had critics invoking the names of Daryl Hall and John Oates as handy frames of reference.

Their latest album, “White Women,” featured guest appearances by Ezra Koenig of Vampire Weekend, Toro y Moi and Solange. And it’s still hard to say just how seriously we’re meant to take them. But for those who like it, chances are that’s half the charm.

Details: 8 p.m. Sunday, April 15. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $30-$45. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/16: In This Moment

Maria Brink and her bandmates are touring in support of “Ritual,” a very heavy album on which they memorably rewrite Billy Idol’s “White Wedding” as “Black Wedding.”

Metal Hammer says it "feels like it’s been created as the soundtrack to In This Moment’s eye-popping Lady Gaga-meets-Rob Zombie live shows rather than a standalone album.”

They conquered rock radio with three songs from 2012’s “Blood” – the title track, “Adrenalize” and “Whore.” Subsequent hits include “Sick Like Me," “Oh Lord” and “Roots.”

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, April 16. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $35. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

4/17: Twiztid

This horrorcore duo from the Detroit suburbs was discovered and groomed by Insane Clown Posse - which could explain the evil clown makeup Jamie Madrox and Monoxide wear onstage.

They're touring in support of "The Continuous Evilution of Life's ?," of which Madrox says, "We really wanted to turn up the volume, mix everything up and push our very existence (musical, spiritual and physical) to its full potential."

Details: 6 p.m. Tuesday, April 17. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $25-$40. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

4/17: The Soft Moon

This tour is in support of "Criminal," a confessional work that views the world "through the stark lens of shame and guilt that has followed Luis Vasquez since a violent childhood growing up within the humming ambient sprawl of 80s Mojave Desert."

The Line of Best Fit praised it as "an album dark and bleak in nature, an exploration that sees him turn his attention to creating hard hitting industrial rock in order to deal with all he's lived through."

Details: 8 p.m. Tuesday, April 17. Valley Bar, 130 N. Central Ave., Phoenix. $15; $13 in advance. 602-368-3121, valleybarphx.com.

4/18: The War on the Drugs

These indie-rock darlings are touring the States in support of “A Deeper Understanding,” an atmospheric gem of an effort that took home Best Rock Album at the Grammys earlier this year and made the Top 10 in best-of-the-year lists at Stereogum and Uncut.

Stereogum praised Adam Granduciel for taking his "idiosyncratic vision of the canon — a vision that takes highway songs and grainy ’70s rock and injects it with a contemporary psychedelia built on droning noises and towering synths — to a new expansiveness."

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, April 18. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $31. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

Randy Cordova contributed to this story.
